liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A man has died after a crash at the Willowbank Raceway in Ipswich, west of Brisbane. Police say his car rolled on the racetrack near Champions Way on Friday. The 41-year-old driver was taken to hospital in a critical condition but has since died from his injuries. The Forensic Crash Unit and Workplace Health and Safety are investigating.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Man dies in hospital after car rolls at racetrack

children.content: A man has died after a crash at the Willowbank Raceway in Ipswich, west of Brisbane.
Police say his car rolled on the racetrack near Champions Way on Friday.
The 41-year-old driver was taken to hospital in a critical condition but has since died from his injuries.
The Forensic Crash Unit and Workplace Health and Safety are investigating.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Online shopping took off during the pandemic, and now with the rising cost-of-living, more of us are being careful with how we spend our hard earned money â even on the essentials. Have you changed how you do your weekly (or fortnightly, or monthly!) shop for those household and grocery items that are traditionally more expensive â like dishwashing tablets, nappies, cleaning products, or that one specific product you just can't find in store? Are you jumping online to get the best possible deal on Amazon, Coles, Woolworths, or another online store? If that sounds like you, we want to hear from you! Business reporter Emily Stewart is exploring how our grocery shopping habits have changed for a story with ABC News â if you want to share your story, get in touch with her by emailing Stewart.Emily@abc.net.au .

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Only one defendant remains on trial over the deadly Whakaari White Island disaster after a judge dismissed charges against two companies this morning. ID Tours Limited and Tauranga Tourism Services were local agents that formed part of the supply chain between tourists from the Ovation of the Seas cruise ship and White Island. They were among the 13 parties charged with breaches of New Zealand's workplace health and safety laws after 22 people died when Whakaari erupted in December 2019. Last week, the two companies applied to have charges against them dismissed and today Judge Evangelos Thomas granted that application. âNeither Tauranga Tourism nor ID Tours had workers on Whakaari, it was never their workplace, they did not influence or direct the workers of the tour operators in the carrying out of their work,â he said while delivering his ruling in Auckland. Also last week, the owners of the volcano Peter, Andrew and Peter Buttle had charges against them dismissed. Their company Whakaari Management Limited is the only party that remains on trial. Five other defendants pleaded guilty before the trial began and a sixth had charges dismissed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More charges dismissed in Whakaari White Island trial

featuredLink.title: More White Island tourism companies have charges dismissed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Consumer confidence has dropped despite the Reserve Bank pausing interest rates for the third month in a row at 4.1 per cent. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute survey of consumer sentiment fell by 1.5 per cent to 79.7 in September from 81 in August. A figure below 100 shows that pessimists outnumber optimists. The confidence of mortgage borrowers lifted 7.8 per cent over August, but confidence fell for renters (-6.1 per cent) and people who own their homes outright (-5.8 per cent). Westpac chief economist Bill Evans says that sentiment has languished at deeply pessimistic levels for more than a year, beaten only by the recession of the 1990s, when even weaker levels of confidence held for more than two years. "Persistent permission has continued despite easing fears of further interest rate rises." "The strong message from survey detail is of ongoing intense pressures on family finances." Mr Evans says a 15 per cent rise in petrol prices over the past two months is worsening concerns about the cost of living, on top of already strong increases in rent and electricity. Confidence in family finances fell by 4.4 per cent over the month, while fewer people thought it was a good time to buy a major household item (-3 per cent).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumer confidence falls despite rate pause

children.content: Consumer confidence has dropped despite the Reserve Bank pausing interest rates for the third month in a row at 4.1 per cent.
survey of consumer sentiment fell by 1.5 per cent to 79.7 in September from 81 in August.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is lower in early trade despite a good night on Wall Street. The benchmark ASX 200 ended higher yesterday after four days of losses. The ASX 200 index is down 0.1 per cent to 7,184. Most sectors are lower led down by energy stocks. Miners have gained after good economic data from China yesterday. Here are the best and worst performers: Telix Pharmaceutical: +4.6% Megaport: +4.3% Pilbara Minerals: +2.8% Syrah Resources: -4.9% Viva Energy: -4.8% Lovisa: -3.6%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: State and federal politicians rank poorly on an ethics index, just above real estate agents. A survey from the Governance Institute says while the perception of politicians has improved, they still rank in the five bottom professions. Journalists are also in the bottom 10 but rank better than social media platforms and payday lenders. The overall Ethics Index score returned to the 2021 figure of 45, having taken a tumble last year. The most ethical occupations were fire services, followed by ambulance services and pharmacists. Governance Institute chief executive Megan Motto spoke to senior business correspondent Peter Ryan.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Politicians ranked just above real estate agents on ethics
